description.narrative:
AAZ har ansökt om stöd från svenska Ambassaden i Lusaka till ett värde av SEK 46 800 00, för att stödja zambiska civilsamhället under perioden 2018 – 2022. Syftet med insatsen är att främja demokratiskt ansvarsutkrävande och transparens, samt att öka kunskap om och möjligheter att kräva mänskliga rättigheter. Fokuset ligger på anti-korruption; hälsorättigheter, miljö och klimat; god samhällsstyrning; och jämställdhet (som genomskär och integreras i hela programmet). AAZ kommer att arbeta genom ett antal olika civilsamhällesorganisationer (CSOs). Svenska Ambassaden ska följaktligen ingå avtal med AAZ, som sedan i sin tur kommer att vidareförmedla stödet till andra CSOs. Östra, Södra, Muchinga, Luapula, Nordvästra, och västra provinserna är AAZs huvudsakliga fokusområden. AAZ kommer också implementera programmet i Lusaka och Copperbelt provinserna för att komplimentera redan existerande insatser där.
Programmets mål är följande;
Mål 1: Stärka CSOs kapasitet att öka medborgares möjligheter att delta i beslutsfattande, och att kräva ansvarstagande, transparens och god samhällsstyrning.
Mål 2: Stärka CSOs och medborgares roll I att främja ansvarsutkrävande och transparens i offentlig finansiell styrning och statens institutionella styrning.
Mål 3: Stärka CSOs och medborgare kapacitet att hålla staten ansvarig för hållbar användning av naturresurser.
Mål 4: Öka tillgång till kvalitativa hälsotjänster genom att stärka CSOs och medborgares kapacitet att kräva kvalitativ sjukvård
Mål 5: Stärka CSOs egna kapacitet att själva efterleva principer om ansvarstagande och transparens.
Sidas stöd kommer att utgöra prjoketstöd för att stödja AAZs landsstrategi. Ambassaden ska bidra med SEK 44 000 000 för detta ändamål. SEK 1 000 000 ska avsättas för en halvtidsutvärdering under 2020. AAZ kommer att bidra med SEK 2 800 000 ur egna medel.

AAZ has applied for a grant from the Embassy of Sweden amounting SEK 46,800,00.00 to support civil society in Zambia for a period of four years, 2018 to 2021. The objective of this initiative is to promote democratic accountability and transparency, and increase awareness and demand for human rights in Zambia through civil society organisations. The Embassy shall enter into an agreement with Action Aid Zambia which shall act as an intermediary organisation to sub-grant to other CSOs as well as provide thematic and institutional capacity buildling. AAZ shall work with different types of CSOs including national, provincial and small grassroots organisations and movements especially women and youth led. This project is expected to contribute to strengthened democratic accountability and transparency and increased awareness and demand for human rights in Zambia with a focus on anti-corruption; health rights and accountability; environment and climate change governance; and gender equality as a cross cutting theme. Eastern, Southern, Muchinga, Luapula, North-Western and Western Provinces will be AAZ’s primary coverage areas while Lusaka and the Copperbelt provinces will be targeted to compliment already existing interventions.
The following are the expected outcomes of the project:
Outcome 1: Strengthened CSOs capacity to enhance citizens’ civic participation and state accountability for improved governance and public service delivery in Zambia. Outcome 2: Strengthened CSOs and citizen’s role in promoting transparency and accountability in public finance management and institutional governance systems. Outcome 3: CSOs & citizens have strengthened capacity in holding government accountable in the enforcement of policies and regulations for sustainable natural resource management and climate justice. Outcome 4: Access to better health is promoted through strengthened capacity of CSOs and citizens to demand for accountability in the provision of quality health care. Outcome 5: Increased CSOs institutional capacity, compliance and accountability among partner Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) in Zambia.
The modality is project support with additional support to their Country Strategy. The Embassy shall contribute SEK44,000,000.00 towards the project and set aside SEK1,000 000.00 for a mid term evalaution aimed at learning in 2020; while AAZ will contribute SEK2,800,000.00.

description.narrative: This conclusion on performance covers the period 2019 and parts of 2020. All reports and annual review meetings in 2020 were delayed due to Covid lockdowns hence the conclusion on performance could not be done at the end of 2020. In addition, there was a costed agreement amendment done for this contribution in December, 2020 to add funds for voter education and local elections observation by civil society organisations (CSOs) in preparation for the August, 2021 general elections. The AAZ support has been the Embassy's flagship civil society support modality through which different types of CSOs and community based organisations (CBOs) have received financial and thematic support in gender equality, environmental justice, health rights and accountability, social accountability, youth and human rights focused programming and institutional capacity building which includes governance and programming. In 2019, 31 grants worth K8,383,395.95 were disbursed. Out of these 12 were standard grants, 7 Community Action Grant type and 12 Social Movement grants. These grants resulted in increased knowledge on human rights by citizens, demand for accountability and protection of human rights defenders. 19 sub-grantees were trained and oriented in financial management; Monitoring and evaluation (M&E) and reporting; compliance and accountability; advocacy; women’s right;and Human rights Based Approaches to programming. To strength CSOs' capacity to enhance citizens’ civic participation and state accountability for improved governance and public service delivery in Zambia, the following were some notable achievements: -30 CSOs were trained in power analysis to improve their analysis of entry points and improve their advocacy work. -80 people were trained (48 females and 15 males and 17 youths) in the budgeting process, budget analysis and tracking in Choma and Chipata. -18 engagements and dialogues human rights and accountability were held by CSOs in project areas. The engagements were held by AAZ and partners in Lusaka, Western, Southern and Northern provinces. As a result of sustained dialogue and advocacy by CSOs to enhance transparency and accountability in the management of Constituency Development Fund (CDF), the following outcomes were attained: - National Level: CDF Act was enacted in 2019 and consequently, constituency development committees(CDC) were created to oversee CDF. CDCs are chaired by an elected Community member while the Council will be monitoring the projects. -At Local Level: The Mongu and Kalabo Councils have given space to CDCs to participate in the planning and monitoring of the CDF Projects to promote accountability and people centred development projects. To build capacities of young people to demand accountability in the health sector and for sexual reproductive health and rights, 122 young people are participating in decision making platforms at all levels. For example, youth in Choma under the Network of people living with HIV, Mazabuka under Copper Rose, and Kasama participate in Ward Development Committees, District Development Committees, Neighbourhood Health Committees, Health Centre Committees, District health communities to speak and present issues that affect them. Through youth participation and engagement, youth friendly health services/SRH services, corners, and safe spaces have been established in Sesheke, Choma and Mazabuka. Climate justice is still a new area for most CSOs in Zambia and it has proven to be even more difficult for community based organisations to grasp the issue in order to adequately sensitise communities. In the period under review 4 CSOs were trained in lobbying and engagement with civic and traditional leaders on management and use of natural resources. 38 meetings on policy e.g Forestry Policy and programmes on NR Management in Choma, Chama, Isoka, Nalolo, Kalabo between sub-grantees and government focusing on climate justice; agro-ecology, environmental protection were held. At national level, CARITAS Zambia (AAZ sub-grantee) held two engagement meetings with the parliamentary committee on Agriculture, land and natural resources to express the CSOs' position on climate change adaption in Zambia. At the same time, another engagement focused on the review of the forestry sector performance and recommendations ware made to Parliament. Through these engagements, Caritas Zambia contributed and influenced Parliamentarians on the need to follow-up on natural resource management in Zambia. In addition, the engagements raised public awareness on the forestry sector performance and CSO position on climate Change. Most project were just starting to implement in 2019 hence alot of results were still at out level. Although it takes long to see impacts in governance projects, the afore stated results show positive strides in the respective areas. The main challenge facing CSOs currently is the shrinking democratic space and harassment of human rights defenders. Innovative approaches such as provision of legal services to support human rights defenders facing arrests and public interest litigation have been designed through this support. CSOs have been able to respond to urgent issues as a result of the flexible nature of this fund which has a mechanism that can fund coalitions of CSOs to mobilise and advocate for the defence of democracy, for instance, the yellow card campaign in July 2019 was funded by this project. The yellow card campaign saw CSOs and ordinary Zambians who gathered within a day to protest outside Parliament and other parts of the Country against the Constitutional Amendment Bill, the closure of the Copper belt University (CBU) and the widespread corruption among government officials among other things. Notably, in January 2020, the Chapter One Foundation through a sub-grant from AAZ, filed a Petition in the Constitutional Court challenging the decision to amend the Constitution of Zambia in the manner it was proposed. A popular human rights defender who was arrested oncharges of unlawful assembly while holding meetings on human rights in Livingstone wasalso represented and was acquitted in August, 2020. AAZ and its partners engagedcommunities and Members of Parliament from various committees to discuss the legalframework relating to the Constitutional Amendment Bill 10; Planning and Budgeting Bill;Mining operations and the APRM. These engagements, contributed to the following results:- Failure to pass bill 10 in the last Parliamentary sitting, where some Members ofParliament walked out of Parliament in protest against bill 10 and the remaining MPscould not form a quorum (two thirds majority) to Pass Bill 10;-The Minister of Finance committed to implement the Planning and Budgeting Bill in2021. The unique financing modalities under this contribution have been shared for learning with other countries through Sida's CSO unit Civsam. AAZ were also invited to make a presentation by Civsam during a global Sida Democracy and Human Rights online network meeting.
